seg.output: Beloved brothers and sisters in Christ our Lord. May the Almighty, faithful and good God strengthen you at all times with the power of His Spirit, so that you and the others may grow in true knowledge of God the Father and our Lord Jesus Christ from day to day. Amen. Knowing, believing, beloved brothers and sisters in Christ, if the great burden and heavy load of my own cross and theirs were not pressing on me, I would willingly leave you in peace, for I have no doubt that you all, together, will be supported by our faithful God, the sign of hope (the cross) of the exalted God. Therefore, I rightly let you rest, knowing that it is fitting to seek comfort from the stronger in weakness and illness. Therefore, I earnestly implore you in the name of God, that you would advise me how I may take up my affairs without detriment to the honor of God; for I can and must not endure in such poverty and need in myself, in my pregnant wife who is still worthily nursing, and in my six children. For if I had not been helped so faithfully and brotherly, I would have had to go into misery a long time ago and would willingly be in it; so that I cannot bear the children, so that they may not themselves go. Besides, my wife cannot come to me, so I am sick and infirm every day and know not how to get along backwards or forwards.

seg.output: Knowing, dear, trusted brothers and lords in Christ, were it not for the great burden and heavy weight of my own cross and those of mine, I would leave you in peace, for I have no doubt that you are all supported by our faithful God, the hope of the eternal God. Therefore I can reasonably leave you in suspense, knowing that it is proper, in weakness and sickness, to seek comfort from the stronger. Therefore I earnestly and sincerely beg you, by God's will, to advise me how I can take care of my own affairs without detriment to the honour of God; for I can and must suffer such poverty and lack in myself, my pregnant wife, who all the time is worthy of respect, and in my six children. Where no one has helped me so faithfully and brotherly, I would have had to go into misery a long time ago and would have been willing to do so; if I cannot sustain the children, they cannot go themselves. Furthermore, my wife can get no help, so I am sick and helpless every day, and know not what to do. Knowing also, dear brothers, that I did not come from Roschach without much cause, and that is one, that I did not get my sustenance; the community wanted to give me help, they said that whoever brought me there should pay me. The pay was well determined by the captain and councillors, but they gave me nothing, nay, I had to sell a cloak at the door and give corn for it. At last the miller took me and my children for his own and justly.

seg.output: Knowing, trusting, beloved brothers and lords in Christ, were it not for the great burden and heavy load of my own cross and others', I would be able to leave you in peace, for I have no doubt that all of you together are comforted by our faithful God, the hope of the redeemed of God. Therefore I leave you without complaint, were it not that I knew it was right to seek solace from the stronger in weakness and sickness. Therefore I earnestly and sincerely beseech you through God's will to advise me how I may take up my cause without detriment to God's honour; for I can and must endure such poverty and want in myself, my pregnant wife who is always worthily nourishing, and in six children I cannot sustain. Had I not been so faithfully and brotherly helped at my expense, I would have long ago had to go into misery and gladly would I have done so; the children cannot endure, so they cannot go. Moreover the woman cannot come hither, so I am myself daily sick and weak, and know neither back nor forth. Knowing also, dear brothers, I have not come from Roschach for great reasons, and one of them is that I have not been able to get my food; the community wanted to give me aid, they said he who would take me there should pay me. The pay was well determined by the captain and council, but they gave me nothing, yea, I had to sell a coat at the door and give it for corn. At last the miller took it from the children for his dues and rightly. At the same time the abbot's father came with his and searched all in my house and found nothing. But the abbot arrested me for all my sweat, and lastly they sold what there was by two beds, which they sent me with my wife and children and are to give me yet a determined compensation of 25 guilders, 17 mallters of corn.

seg.output:
Knowing, trustworthy, loving brothers and lords in Christ, if it were not for the great burden and the heavy burden of my own cross and that of others, I would be able to leave you in peace, for I have no doubt that all of you are comforted together by our faithful God, the hope of (the cross) of the exalted God. Therefore, I would kindly be silent, if I did not know that it befits one in weakness and sickness to seek the comfort of the stronger. Therefore, I earnestly ask you in the name of God, if you would give me advice as to how I can take care of my affairs without detriment to the honor of God; for I can and must not bear in such need and lack in myself, my pregnant wife, who is always worthy of nourishment, and six children. If I had not been helped so faithfully and brotherly, I would have had to go a long time into misery and would have been willing to do so; so I cannot bear the children, so they cannot go themselves. Moreover, as the woman cannot come anywhere, I am myself sick and helpless every day and know neither back nor forth. Also knowing, dear brothers, that I did not come from Roschach for any great reason, and that is one, I did not accept my nourishment; the community wanted to give it to me, they said, he who would take me there should pay me. The pay was well determined by the captain and council, but they gave me nothing, yes I had to sell a coat at the door and give for grain. Lastly, the miller took it from the children around the same and fairly. To the same came the father of the abbot with his and searched all in my house and found nothing. Besides, the abbot also confiscated all the sweat, and lastly they sold what was there by two beds, which they sent me with wife and children and should give me still a determined compensation 25 guilders, 17 bushels of grain. There will never be more to me, for it should have been given from the monastery property. This is now all gone and done.
Therefore, my dear, trustworthy brothers, advise me how I should start my life. Therefore, my dear, trustworthy brothers, advise me how I should start my life. I am ashamed of begging, so I cannot work, so I cannot leave my wife and children. Therefore, my dear, trustworthy brothers, advise me how I should start my life. I am ashamed of begging, so I cannot work, so I cannot leave my wife and children. In sum, may the true God prevent my flesh from succumbing to what the inner man struggles and resists with strength from God.

seg.output: Beloved brothers and sisters in Christ our Lord. Almighty, faithful and good God may always strengthen you with the power of His Spirit, so that you and your companions may increase day by day in true knowledge of God the Father and of our Lord Jesus Christ. Amen. Knowing, faithful, beloved brothers and sisters in Christ, if I didn't bear the great burden and the heavy yoke of my own cross and of yours, I would be able to leave you in peace, for I have no doubt that all of you together are comforted by our faithful God and the hope of the blessed God. Therefore, I rightly leave you undone, if I didn't know that it is fitting to ask for comfort from the stronger in weakness and sickness. Therefore, I earnestly and faithfully beseech you by God's will to advise me how I should take my case without detriment to God's honor; for I can and must not bear such poverty and lack in myself, my pregnant wife, who is always worthy of grace, and six children. If no one has helped me so faithfully and brotherly, I would have had to go into misery long ago and would gladly do so; I can not bear the children, so they can not go themselves. Moreover, my woman can not come, so I am sick and infirm every day and know neither backwards nor forwards.

seg.output: Knowing, trusting, beloved brothers and lords in Christ, were it not for the great burden and the heavy weight of my own cross and others', I would leave you in peace, for I do not doubt that all of you together are also supported by our faithful God, the hope of the redeemed. Therefore, I would not begrudge you, were I not aware that it is fitting in weakness and sickness to seek comfort from the stronger. Therefore, I earnestly and faithfully beg you all through God's will to give me counsel as to how I may take up my cause without detriment to the honour of God; for I can and must not endure such poverty and lack in myself, my pregnant wife, who is worthily nourished at all times, and six children. Had not help been given to me in a brotherly manner, I would have had to go a long time ago into misery, and would have gladly done so; I cannot bear the children; thus, they cannot go themselves. Moreover, the woman cannot come anywhere; thus, I am myself sick and feeble every day and know not whence to bring help. Knowing also, beloved brothers, that I did not come of my own free will to Roschach, and one thing is that I did not accept my nourishment; the community wanted to give me aid, saying that he who brought me there should pay me. The pay was to be determined by the captain and councillors, but they gave me nothing, yea, I had to sell a coat at the door and give grain for it. Lastly, the miller took my sons and me for a reasonable amount.

seg.output: Knowing, trustworthy, beloved brothers and lords in Christ, if I did not feel the great burden and the heavy yoke of my own cross and of those of mine, I would leave you in peace, for I do not doubt that all of you together are also comforted by our faithful God, the hope of salvation (cross) of the exalted God. Therefore, I should rightly leave you ungrateful, if I did not know that it is fitting in weakness and illness to seek comfort from the stronger. Therefore, I most faithfully and earnestly beg you, through God's will, to give me advice as to how I might take up my affair without detriment to God's honor; for I cannot and may not endure in such poverty and need in myself, my pregnant wife, who is worthily nourished all the time, and in six children. If one had not helped me so faithfully and brotherly out of expense, I would have had to go into misery long ago and would even have been willing to do so; so I cannot bear the children, so they cannot go themselves. Moreover, the woman cannot come anywhere, so I am sick and helpless myself every day and do not know how to put together before or behind. Also knowing, dear brothers, that I did not come from Roschach for great cause, and it is one, that I did not pay my nourishment; the community wanted to give me help, they said, whoever took me there should pay me. The pay should have been determined by the captain and council, but they gave me nothing, yes I had to sell a coat at the door and give grain. Lastly, the miller took me for the grain and rightly. At the same time the abbot's father came with his and searched everything in my house and found nothing. By that the abbot also took me all the sweat, and at last they sold what was there, two beds, which they sent me with wife and children and shall give me a determined compensation of 25 guilders, 17 bushels of grain.

Knowing, trustful, beloved brothers and lords in Christ, were it not for the great burden and the heavy yoke of my own cross and that of mine, I would leave you in peace, for I do not doubt that all of you are supported by our faithful God, the hope (the cross) of the redeemed of God. Therefore, I justly ask for your help, were it not that I knew it to be appropriate to seek comfort from the stronger in weakness and sickness. Therefore, I earnestly and sincerely ask you, by God's will, to advise me as to how I should handle my affairs without detriment to God's honor, for I cannot and do not have the means to bear such poverty and need in myself, my pregnant wife, who is worthily nourished at all times, and six children. Were it not for the cost, so faithfully and brotherly provided by you, I would have had to go into misery a long time ago and would have gladly done so; so I cannot support the children, so they cannot go themselves. Furthermore, the wife cannot come anywhere, so I am sick and weak myself every day and know neither how to go back nor forward. Knowing also, dear brothers, that I did not come to Roschach without great cause, and that one is that I have not received my sustenance; the village wanted to give me nothing, they said that whoever would take me there should pay for me. The pay was to be determined by the captain and council, but they gave me nothing, yes, I had to sell a coat at the door and give in exchange for grain. Finally, the miller took the hay from the children and justly. At the same time the abbot's father came with his and searched everything in my house and found nothing. In addition, the abbot also took all my sweat, and in the end they sold what was there, two beds, which they sent me with wife and children and should give me another 25 fl., 17 malters of grain. I will never be at ease about it, as it should have been given to me from the cloister's goods.
That is now all and done. Therefore, my beloved, trustful brothers, advise me how I should begin my life. I am ashamed of begging, so I cannot work, so I cannot leave my wife and children. In sum, may the true God forbid that my flesh should do what it desires, however the inner man fights and resists with God's strength.

An Meyster Heinrichen Bullingern und sine mitt arbeytter im wortt gotts Zürich, mine gliebtten bruͤder, H. E.
seg.output: Dear beloved, faithful brothers, advise me how I should lead my life. I am poor and cannot work, so I cannot support my wife and children. In short, may the true God forgive that my flesh does not obey, even though the inner man fights and resists with God's strength. But great poverty presses so hard that I cannot resist the crosswind. Is there any comfort and encouragement among you in this my misery, I beseech you through God that you will not spare yourselves, as I then trust you, and to me as a comfortless one advise how I should do, so that I remain until the end and receive eternal life with you, my beloved brothers. Amen. May the merciful God grant you all grace together. Amen.
